author: Ben Morgan
title: City broker: how I tackled masked men using nunchucks and my martial arts training
text:
Six killed and eight wounded in terror attack on Quebec mosque 
A City broker has told how he fought off two masked men with nunchuck s outside his home when they tried to steal his motorbike. 
Father-of-one Dino Bergonzi, 47, caught the two men - clad in balaclavas, motorbike leathers and helmets - as they were trying to steal his Vespa Piaggio MP3 which was parked on his driveway. 
He ran outside with his martial arts weapon to confront the pair, but one of the thieves grabbed the nunchucks off him and lashed out at him. 
However, Mr Bergonzi wrestled with his attacker before neighbour came out to help, forcing the thieves to abandon the motorcycle and flee. 
The attempted robbery was captured on CCTV , which Mr Bergonzi - who lives near Streatham Common - installed after his son’s scooter had been stolen by a gang of moped-riding thieves weeks before. Police are hunting two supects after the violent clash 
Mr Bergonzi - who has been studying the martial art Krav Maga for three years at West Norwood Health and Leisure Centre - told the Standard: “I was sat in my office when I saw these two guys on a motorbike looking completely wrong. 
“I’d had cameras installed after my son’s bike was stolen and I watched them walk across the drive where my car and bike were parked. They were completely brazen. 
“I picked up a stick, which folds out into nunchucks, and went outside. One man was behind my motorbike screwing the number plate off. 
“He saw me coming and put the screw driver down and started crying, saying ‘I’m sorry, I’m sorry’. 
“I realised he was only fourteen or fifteen years old and I didn’t know what would happen. The second suspect sought by police 
“Then his friend turned up with the bike. I was distracted and he grabbed the nunchucks and he hit me several times. 
“I couldn’t take on them both so I rushed the guy with the nunchucks and he dropped them.” 
Two neighbours, one carrying a baseball bat, rushed out to help Mr Bergonzi before the two men ran off. 
They returned minutes later to retrieve the motorbike they arrived on, which police later said was also stolen. 
Mr Bergonzi urged the public to know their rights and how to defend themselves before they become ‘have a go heroes’.
